description:
Much of the power of GIMP, the GNU Image Manipulation program, comes from its plug-in architecture. Most of the functions you use in GIMP, including everything in the Filters menu, are plug-ins.

In this tutorial, you’ll learn to write your own GIMP plug-ins in two languages: Script-fu and Python.

Script-Fu is GIMP’s native language, installed in every version of GIMP. Script-fu is a variant of Scheme, but you don’t need to be fluent in Scheme or Lisp to write Script-fu. You just need to know a few basics of Lisp syntax and how to find the right GIMP call to do what you need. I’ll also cover some of the script-fu changes introduced in 2.4, how to update older scripts, and how to make sure your new scripts will run on all GIMP versions.

The second half of the tutorial will cover Python, rapidly becoming the language of choice for GIMP plug-ins because of its flexibility and clean API. You’ll see how Python’s access to raw pixel data in an image gives it a huge advantage over Script-fu, and how you can use Python-GTK to create user interfaces far beyond GIMP’s usual plug-in dialogs.

If possible, bring a laptop with GIMP 2.6 and Python installed. You’ll have a chance to write your own plug-ins and try them for yourself.
title: Writing GIMP Plug-ins and Scripts
